Award.AwardTitle: CSBR: Natural History Collections: Completing the rehabilitation of the orphaned USGS fossil invertebrate collection at the University of California Museum of Paleontology
Award.AbstractNarration:
In 1997 the University of California Museum of Paleontology (UCMP) accepted responsibility for the extensive invertebrate collection (170,000 fossils from 12,100 localities) from the United State Geological Survey (USGS), Menlo Park. Unfortunately, the comprehensive documentation stored with the fossils was not preserved as archival material and is deteriorating. Moreover, during the move the collection was scrambled, many of the wooden cases damaged, and the doors lost. In 1998, one third of the collection was integrated into UCMP's main collection. This project will (1) re-house the remaining two thirds of the collection in museum-grade cabinets, (2) reorganize, re-label, and digitally capture the contents of the drawers, and (3) digitally capture and store the documentation in archival media.

This collection, largely from the West coast of North America from the last 25 million years, is unique and irreplaceable. It has generated over 1,000 publications, including systematic and biostratigraphic studies, paleoecological and paleoclimatic research, resource assessments, and geologic surveys. This project will provide important curatorial experiences for graduate students and will also engage undergraduate students in authentic research activities. The Berkeley's Biology Scholars Program, which promotes the success of students from economic, gender, ethnic and cultural groups historically underrepresented in biology, will assist with undergraduate recruitment. The project will also provide increased science awareness to a broader public audience as we make available, both physically and digitally, this world-class paleontological collection.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 1997, the University of California Regents accessioned the United States Geological Survey (USGS) orphaned invertebrate fossil collection previously stored in Menlo Park, CA. The 2012 NSF-CSBR grant to the University of California Museum of Paleontology (UCMP) funded the purchase of sixty custom fabricated steel collections cabinets, drawers, and acid-free specimen trays were purchased to house these UCMP collections. During the past three years, UCMP staff and students transferred over 100,000 individual fossils from overcrowded trays and unsealed wooden cabinets to new acid-free paper trays in archival museum drawers and cabinets. The fossils include mollusks: bivalves, gastropods, cephalopods and scaphopods, as well as echinoids, decapods, and barnacles. The removal of fossils from wooden cabinets is an important step to counter the effects of acid leaching out of wood that could react with mollusk shells composed of calcium carbonate, causing a recrystallization of shell microstructure that irreparably damages specimens. To ensure that this does not occur, the fossil clams, snails and other shells were transferred to acid-free paper trays, accompanied by updated acid-free paper labels. These improved storage conditions and reorganization will ensure that this scientifically significant and irreplaceable collection, made primarily by geologists mapping the rock units of the Pacific coast from Canada to Mexico, will continue to be available for study by future researchers and scientists.

This grant provided the resources to make this major invertebrate collection digitally accessible for the first time. Records for 18,000 fossil collecting localities were added to the searchable UCMP database (http://ucmpdb.berkeley.edu/loc.html) and available to the public, citizen scientists, students, and researchers for the first time. Spanning the last 200 million years of history on the Pacific coast, with a focus on the last 23 million years, this collection provides an impressive treasure trove of data critical to a better understanding of species origination and extinction as well as changing climate and ocean currents. Currently one-third of the fossil localities have accurate latitude and longitude coordinates, facilitating the use of climate models and other place-based research. High-resolution photographs of these fossils are now also available online from hundreds of localities (http://tinyurl.com/usgsmpphotos). Serving the photographs online provides answers to many questions UCMP receives from researchers inquiring about the collections, such as the number and type of fossils as well as the mode of fossil preservation at specific localities.  

Important archival materials arrived literally in the original wooden drawers of specimens or scattered on top. These included original reports, field notes, photographs and first-hand documentation of many of the geologist’s field observations. Preserving these materials greatly enhances the scientific and historical importance of the collection. These materials will eventually be linked to the fossil specimens through the UCMP’s archival database.

During the course of the project, U.C. Berkeley students participated alongside UCMP staff in a “hands-on” learning environment to fulfill the goals of the project. Eight diverse undergraduates with an interest in natural history and three graduate students received training in specimen curation and collections management. Through direct interaction with museum staff, they enriched their skills in specimen handling, database management, archival file types and digital imaging.
